timeline.title: 12–18 Months Before Intake
timeline.subtitle: Explore destinations, budgets, and target programs.
actions: Shortlist 5–8 programs aligned with your goals
Map tuition + living + buffer; compare ROI

timeline.title: 10–12 Months: Tests & Prep
timeline.subtitle: Book and prepare for language/standardized tests.
actions: For STEM/Business: Plan GRE/GMAT if required
Take diagnostic, set weekly study targets

timeline.title: 8–10 Months: SOP & LORs
timeline.subtitle: Craft your story; secure recommendations.
actions: Draft Statement of Purpose with clear goals

timeline.title: 6–8 Months: Submit Applications
timeline.subtitle: Apply early for better scholarship odds.
actions: Track each application status in a sheet

timeline.title: 5–7 Months: Scholarships & Funding
timeline.subtitle: Target merit- and need-based options.
actions: Apply to university and external scholarships

timeline.title: 3–5 Months: Offers & Deposits
timeline.subtitle: Compare offers; confirm seat.
actions: Pay deposit; request CAS/I-20 where applicable

timeline.title: 2–3 Months: Visa & Compliance
timeline.subtitle: Gather financials; book appointment.
actions: Scan & organize all PDFs to a single drive

timeline.title: 0–1 Month: Arrival & Registration
timeline.subtitle: Get campus-ready; sort local essentials.
actions: Open bank account, get local SIM

timeline.title: 10–12 Months: Executive Exams (as needed)
timeline.subtitle: GMAT Executive/English tests for mid-career programs.
actions: Gather proof of experience for waivers

timeline.title: 6–9 Months: Targeted Networking
timeline.subtitle: Align future roles with program outcomes.

interviews.title: Behavioral — General
interviews.subtitle: Use STAR, quantify outcomes, and reflect on learnings.
tips: Keep answers 1–2 minutes; avoid rambling.
Highlight your direct contribution and impact.
Prepare 4–5 strong STAR stories you can remix.

qas.sample: Engineer with 2 yrs in fintech; scaled payments by 40%...
Mediated priority conflict by quantifying impact...
Shipped without full QA; introduced checklist and CI

interviews.title: Technical — Fresh Grad (Software)
interviews.subtitle: DSA foundations, code clarity, and testing.
tips: Narrate approach before coding.
Start with brute force, then optimize.
Write tests for edge cases.

qas.sample: Time O(n), space O(n) for map

interviews.title: Career Transition — Experienced
interviews.subtitle: Translate previous wins to new domain outcomes.
tips: Quantify impact with $$, %, time saved.
Map old responsibilities to new JD keywords.
Show quick learning via projects/certs.

qas.sample: Observed X trend; upskilled; piloted project Y...

interviews.title: Product Sense Basics
interviews.subtitle: Users, problems, metrics, and trade-offs.
tips: Define target user and JTBD before solutions.
Pick one north-star metric and 2 guardrails.
Call out risks and experiments.

qas.sample: Hypothesize drop at step 2; test shorter form

qas.q: Pick a metric for feature Y

interviews.title: Case Interview — Consulting
interviews.subtitle: Structure, MECE, and sanity checks.
tips: Restate prompt and align on goal.
Draw a simple, MECE structure.
Do math out loud; round cleanly.

interviews.title: Academic Admissions Interview
interviews.subtitle: Fit to program, readiness, and potential.
tips: Connect curriculum to your goals.
Discuss 1–2 faculty or labs of interest.
Reflect on resilience and growth.

qas.sample: Course A + Lab B map to my goal of...

interviews.title: Research Assistant Interview
interviews.subtitle: Methodology, rigor, and writing.
tips: Summarize a recent paper’s method and limitations.
Explain your data cleaning & versioning approach.
Share a writing sample or poster.

qas.q: How do you handle missing data?
qas.sample: MAR vs MCAR; imputation vs deletion

interviews.title: Healthcare Interview
interviews.subtitle: Empathy, compliance, and safety.
tips: Use de-identified examples.
Tie actions to patient outcomes.
Safety mindset over speed.

qas.q: A time you managed a critical situation

interviews.title: Design Portfolio Review
interviews.subtitle: Process, decisions, and iteration.
tips: Show problem framing and constraints.
Demonstrate user insights → decisions.
Call out trade-offs and alt explorations.

interviews.title: Sales & GTM Interview
interviews.subtitle: Pipeline, discovery, and objection handling.
tips: Quantify pipeline coverage and win rate.
Know your ICP and use cases.
Handle objections with proof points.

qas.sample: Budget, authority, timeline; next steps set

resume.title: Header & Contact
resume.subtitle: Clean, ATS-friendly contact info at the top.
resume.summary: Use a single line: Name · Email · Phone · City · LinkedIn/GitHub/Portfolio.
dos: Use a professional email and clear LinkedIn URL.
donts: No profile photo or graphics for ATS.

examples.heading: Good
examples.text: Aarav Sharma · aarav@proton.me · +91-98xxxxxxx · Bengaluru, IN · linkedin.com/in/aarav · github.com/aarav-sh

resume.title: Professional Summary
resume.subtitle: A 2–3 line value statement, not an objective.
resume.summary: Tailor to the JD; show scope, domain, and impact.
dos: Mention years of experience and core stack.

examples.heading: Example
examples.text: Data analyst (3+ yrs) in e-commerce; built SQL/BI dashboards used by 8 teams; drove 12% lift in weekly conversions via A/B tests.

resume.title: Education
resume.subtitle: List most recent first; add highlights.
resume.summary: Add degree, institution, grad month/year, GPA (if strong), and 1–2 relevant courses or awards.
dos: Include thesis/project if relevant to role.
Show top courses aligned to JD.

examples.heading: Undergrad
examples.text: B.Tech, Computer Science — NIT Trichy · 2025 · GPA 8.6/10 · Courses: DS&A, DBMS, ML · Merit Scholarship

resume.title: Experience
resume.subtitle: Impact bullets with strong verbs and metrics.
resume.summary: 3–5 bullets per role; each bullet = action + metric + outcome.
dos: Start with verbs: Led, Built, Automated, Reduced.
Quantify with %, time, cost, or revenue.
Group related wins; keep tense consistent.
donts: Don’t bury top wins in the middle.

examples.heading: Bullet
examples.text: Built ETL in Python to consolidate 5 sources; reduced reporting time by 70% (2h → 36m) and improved data freshness to <15m.

resume.title: Projects
resume.subtitle: Showcase relevant, recent, and shipped work.
resume.summary: 2–3 projects with links; call out users, stack, and results.
dos: Quantify users, latency, or accuracy improvements.
donts: Don’t omit role if team project.

examples.heading: Example
examples.text: Smart Notes (React/Flask): semantic search over 2k notes; 350 MAU; reduced lookup time by 60%.

resume.title: Skills
resume.subtitle: Group by category; be honest about level.
resume.summary: Keep it scannable; prefer 2–3 columns grouped by category.
donts: Avoid long comma lists with duplicates.
No fake proficiency; you may be tested.
Don’t include obsolete tech unless relevant.

examples.heading: Grouping
examples.text: Languages: Python, JS · Data: SQL, Pandas · Cloud: GCP (BQ) · Tools: Git, Docker, Airflow

resume.title: Achievements & Certifications
resume.subtitle: Only high-signal items from the last 3–5 years.
resume.summary: Show ranked wins, publications, or relevant certs.
dos: Include vendor and year for certs.

resume.title: Formatting & ATS
resume.subtitle: One page (early career), clean fonts, and consistent spacing.
resume.summary: Use simple bullets, 10–11pt body, and 0.5–0.75in margins.
dos: Export to PDF; test with plain-text paste.
Use consistent mm/dd/yyyy or Mon YYYY format.
donts: No tables, images, or multi-column for ATS.
Don’t exceed 2 pages unless truly senior.
